revisions.rev:
:''For the mountain ranges in Nevada, see'' [[East Humboldt Range]] and [[West Humboldt Range]] {{coord|71|45|S|11|30|E|display=title|type:mountain}} '''Humboldt Mountains''' is a group of [[mountain]]s immediately west of the [[Petermann Ranges]], forming the westernmost portion of the [[Wohlthat Mountains]] in [[Queen Maud Land]], [[Antarctica]]. They were discovered and mapped by the [[Third German Antarctic Expedition]] (1938â1939), led by Capt. [[Alfred Ritscher]], who named them for [[Alexander von Humboldt]], famed German naturalist and geographer of the first half of the nineteenth century.<ref name=gnis>{{cite gnis|type=antarid|id=7157|name=Humboldt Mountains|accessdate=2007-03-12}}</ref> __NOTOC__
==Geological features== ==== Mount Skarshovden ==== Mount Skarshovden ({{coord|71|47|S|11|38|E|type:mountain}}) is a rounded [[mountain]], 2,830 m, surmounting the western side of [[Hovdeskar Gap]]. It was discovered and photographed by the [[Third German Antarctic Expedition]], 1938â39, mapped by Norway from air photos and surveys by [[Sixth Norwegian Antarctic Expedition|Norwegian Antarctic Expedition]], 1956â60, and named Skarshovden ("the gap mountain").<ref>{{cite gnis|type=antarid|id=13924|name=Mount Skarshovden|accessdate=2007-03-12}}</ref>
==== Yanovskiy Rocks ==== Yanovskiy Rocks ({{coord|71|56|S|11|40|E|}}) are two isolated rock outcrops lying {{convert|8|km|mi|0}} south of [[Mount Khmyznikov]] near the southeast end of the Humboldt Mountains. First mapped from air photos and surveys by [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]], 1960â61, and named after Soviet hydrographer [[S.S. Yanovskiy]].<ref>{{cite gnis|type=antarid|id=16862|name=Yanovskiy Rocks|accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref>
